pros:
Great Students - I have been teaching part-time as an Adjunct for UMUC for over 10 years. It is a great place to work. The students are excellent and mostly dedicated to their studies. Many are military and very driven towards success. 

Little/No Micromanagement - If you have a proven track record for performing excellent course delivery, you are not micromanaged, which I have seen in other colleges/universities.

Minimum Course Setup - Most courses are already completely designed/setup in the D2L/LEO Learning Management System, meaning you don't have to spend countless hours setting up the course and/or crafting initial discussions.
cons:
Adjunct Faculty are only allowed 5 courses per year. Meaning the total yearly pay isn't typically enough for it to be a sole job, even for a person only wanting to work part-time, causing one to have to work elsewhere as well.

Little Network Opportunity - Not much opportunity to network with colleagues. 

No Academic Freedom - When I first started teaching for UMUC, Faculty had much more Academic Freedom to control what they opted to teach in the course. Now, there is little to no opportunity to interject one's vast knowledge and expertise on the subject matter of the course, except through the discussions, which even many of them are already determined. Faculty have gone from the role of teaching their expertise on the subject, to being a facilitator monitoring students' progress on the material already designated as being 'worthy' of being in the course content.

review_title: I Don't Know About You But....
job_title: Administrative Assistant/Receptionist in College Park, MD
pros: I enjoyed my work, as well as my supervisor. My supervisor was different than my manager. So I appreciated her buffer from time to time when it came to some things my manager would say that I may or may not have understood. There is not much else positive I can say about working at UMUC, as it was not a very enjoyable place to work, nor did they give me benefits, even as a "student" employee, even though I was not a student attending that school They did not tell me it was a student position. So at the end, when they said my term was up because it was a student position, I was very confused, because I wasn't a student.
cons: When it came to letting people go, they one day fired someone, and had them leave immediately, but for no reason. When it came to letting me go, they gave me the impression that I would be staying, but at the end said they needed someone with more experience, and yet they hired someone with less experience who was incompetent once I was gone, per the complaints of former coworkers of mine. The manager that I had was very hostile and insensitive to some of my coworkers, as well as myself. She walked right over them, and didn't seem as competent and well-rounded in her position as a manager should be. The environment was often tense within the office, and I did not feel comfortable there after a while.

pros: Great work environment, very collaborative, great benefits.

pros:
If you can get on as "permanent," the benefits are good-- leave time, health insurance. 
I work remotely and don't have to commute and can work from anywhere with Internet.
I like working with students and professors-- good people.
State benefits are good.
Pay is not bad for working online. 
I've learned a lot from the work. 
Tuition reimbursement.
cons:
There are too many administrators. It's really crazy. This department has 6 administrators and fewer than 20 staff. The administrators do very little work from what I can see. A couple are quite hostile and actually resent the better workers. No one seems ever to evaluate the administrators, though they're constantly evaluating the staffers. No one in 7 years has ever asked me about whether the administrators are helpful to our job.
Also, there's some wage theft going on. The pay's okay so I've stopped complaining, but I frequently have to work more than I'm allowed to bill. Also, I was a "temporary employee" for about 3 years, apparently so that I wouldn't get access to benefits. I think both of those are illegal, but no one's paying attention, and when I mentioned this to HR, they ignored me. But the pay is okay for online work.

review_title: Gain work experience, then move on!!
pros: Great coworkers, a ton of time off, great entry-level job.
cons: Way too top-heavy. As a result, managers have nothing more to do than micromanage. This is a sales job! They literally stopped teaching new hires content and started implementing sales training. They do not care about quality, only quantity. It is a non-profit organization that operates like a for-profit. The only way to move up is to suck up. Management walks around and does not bother to even say 'hello', but they expect people show loyalty and go above and beyond for them (such as work extra hours with no incentive). Untrustworthy management. High turnover. Budget cuts have led to massive layoffs.

pros: Leave package is amazing. Eligible for state benefits if you are regular, however, they mostly hire at contingent. Monthly lectures with free lunch. On-site cafeteria.
cons: Difficult to move up, they say they will hire internally but end up going externally which creates a huge learning curve for the new hire. Management is not hired based on experience in higher education from a non-profit perspective, but instead based on for-profit criteria and sales/marketing. Marketing is taking over the advising and not making it student focused. The institution uses the same failing techniques each year and the lower paid employees are suffering in the form of layoffs and contract non-renewals over the past few years.

review_title: Employee loyalty comes from trust not power
pros: With the recent change to a non-profit, I hope the salary competitiveness will change in the near future in the university.
cons: coercive culture, untrustworthy leadership, low salaries, old technology, lower quality of education, number of students in classes doubled in the last two years, lack of proper support for students, student feedback is not utilized to improve the organization.

pros: Good benefits including tuition remission, and there is potential for growth within the university. There is a clear path for advancement so even if you remain in the same position for several years you do have opportunities to grow within that role.
cons: The university never has a clear direction, especially within Enrollment Management. Every 6 months to a year the departments are completely restructured to support UMUC's "new direction" that will carry them forward. Additionally more emphasis is placed on meeting short term enrollment goals than actually servicing existing students correctly, meaning that most time is spent on outreaches that would result in contacting the same students repeatedly throughout the term instead of ensuring our current students were enrolled in the correct classes.

review_title: Never thought it could be me!
pros: Great Co-workers, made good friends within other units, pay was good, benefits were excellent, and sometimes could work from home.
cons: I was part of the lay off group that happen this year 2014. I thought I would move around in the company, but was let go not because of performance but due to budget constraints. I saw a lot of organizational moves within my unit some good and some bad. I would not have imaged that I was going to be let go. I have been working at the company for 2 years full-time.

review_title: 4+ years, gratitude is the right attitude.
pros: I've been working here for 4+ years, in two separate departments. My managers knew I was interested in working in higher education and helped me foster that desire. Consequently, I moved on to a new position in a different department. Folks who complain about their entry-level position do little to nothing to gain skills or talent to get out and instead complain about their good situation.  Salary, benefits, leave, fringe benefits (ex. teleworking), tuition remission, snow days, are all fair to great.
cons: UMUC is continuously attempting to be the driving force in higher education, and this lends itself to constantly reinventing itself in various ways. It makes it hard to keep up at times! The university does not have a clear system of promoting talent from within. Beyond entry-level positions at the university is a completely different world. Keep that in mind when reading review.

review_title: Great people, lousy, inconsistent, immature management
pros: UMUC is fortunate to have a great staff.  Personnel are all very well educated.  The benefits are excellent.  Paid time off (including sick leave, vacation time, and personal leave) is well above average, especially for new employees.
cons: Leadership is weak.  Management decisions are made with a shoot from the hip mentality.  Management has created a hostile environment where staff constantly feel like someone is looking over their shoulder.  Support for staff is non-existent.  Management pays lip service to the proposition that management wants to help staff to be successful.

pros: Vacation time to get away from this crazy place!
cons: Do not accept a non-exempt or contingent position with UMUC. Exempt employees take advantage of the benefits and hourly employees suffer and its unfair. How can you allow a salary employee to take comp time hour for hour just because they have to stay late a few hours twice a month and get to telework twice a week??  If you complain to senior management they do nothing! Underpaid and no chance for advancement. Been here for over 2 years and have applied for other positions I'm well qualified for and don't get an interview!

pros: Compared to other online adjunct positions, the pay is very fair. They schedule ahead of time--there's better security (I know my upcoming schedule for the next two semesters). Good communication, and they show trust in their faculty--there's no nitpicking oversight. The courses are pre-designed and thoughtful. The students are mostly active duty service members, and they're pretty disciplined. Friendly staff. Overall, the university does seem really dedicated to their students--I find the courses to be designed really thoughtfully.
cons: Only the cons that exist for every adjunct position--lack of job security (though UMUC is a bit better than most), low pay, no benefits, no opportunity for career growth. UMUC is at least trying to address these issues, which I appreciate.

pros: Excellent company with wonderful coworkers and unlimited advancement potential.  Great mission and dedicated leaders. HR has many wonderful projects that get the full support of the President and so things are always improving and exciting.
cons: HR is now under new management and we couldn't be happier. Removing bullies who abuse power will align HR with the rest of this fine organization. Everyone wants to learn and grow under a Jedi, not a dark lord!!

review_title: UMUC is not what it seems
pros: Co-workers are usually nice and most of the employees truly care about the students. People in student service / enrollment management departments are trying to help the students.
cons: The management does not support the employees. People are being let go en masse with no explanation. Anyone who questions the decisions being made will be shown the door. There is no room to move up within the university unless you are willing to kiss up to the right people. Long gone are the days of hard work and determination helping you move up.

review_title: Good people but little advancement opportunity
pros:
Great benefits.
Great people.
Outside of the Enrollment Management department, the university was a great place to work - fair pay, great benefits, and management who cared about their staff instead of the numbers.
The mission of the university was a very positive one that I (and much of the staff) believe in.
cons:
The culture of "enroll no matter what" lead to some bitterness in lower-level staff.
Advancement opportunities are only available if you know the right people.
The break-up of the locations for the various departments made communication and support much more difficult.
Pay freezes made raises non-existent.

pros:

Work from home
cons: IT is losing good people faster than they can hire them.  The people they don't lose are labeled as useless and no attempt is made to increase their skills or motivate them.  Instead contractors are brought in to do the work. Groups doing modern technology appear to be there to work around older groups.  Jive is used for collaboration but appears mainly to be a place to broadcast messages and not do anything that might cause offense to someone.  HR is near worthless.  After 8 months there my benefits that I signed up for were still not correct nor my hire date.  If high-level end users must be appeased, good contractors are used, knowing that they will have to then be fired as the end user will never be satisfied.  Big plans, few that can deliver.

pros: Independent position with decent salary (although with furloughs).  Well funded with lots of gadgets.  Rewarding job helping people.
cons: HUGE turnover and no respect for those with longevity.  Little reward no matter how hard you work.  Management was in early 20's and didn't have clue, would not listen to established employees, and worked hard to make a good job difficult and communication limited.  Had over 10 weeks of vacation accumulated yet new management  wanted 3 weeks notice to take a personal day to attend son's field trip.

pros: The benefits are better than the pay. The environment is relaxed and the people are nice. It's a diverse organization.
cons: IT management waste a lot of money on infrastructure improvements especially in the realm of audiovisual equipment. Advancement is tricky. From what I have seen its not what you know it's who you know. Retention needs to be better for IT professionals. I have seen two directors and two managers leave within a year.

review_title: Academic Advisor for a short stint
pros: Great benefits and starting pay for someone fresh out of college. You get about a month of training before they let you loose.
cons: It had a very "Big Brother" feel. Everyone was super concerned about their time spent on calls, idle, etc. People were sacrificing bathroom breaks to meet certain goals. There was a sense of paranoia when taking calls since they get randomly listened in on to maintain UMUC standards. I got offered a job shortly after finishing training and left though so my experience was just a glimpse of the real deal.

pros: Great colleagues, great benefits, solid infrastructure.
cons: UMUC is turning into a for profit overnight. One month ago we were force fed new outreach plans and when people didn't implement they got fired. Anyone who won't use for profit methods is leaving or getting let go. Lay offs are rolling through every department. Consultants have been brought in from the for-profit, are walking the halls and noting everything that needs to change in order to turn us into a for profit University. If you are fine with targets and can be overly zealous you might be fine here. If you background is in hard core sales, you might do well. Don't come here looking for a public university experience.

pros: State retirement benefits are good if you stay for seven years, three or more weeks of leave when you start, opportunities to learn, tuition remission benefits
cons: Lower than average salary, overzealous CIO has nearly everyone working overtime, too many meetings to discuss new or ongoing projects, teams constantly being downsized, real money goes into outsourced development (e.g. PeopleSoft, Java), too many legacy systems, difficult to get app released to production, inter-department politics slow things down, too many generals (managers) and not enough soldiers (developers, engineers), too much obsession with ITIL and agile, the economics of university enrollments can affect employment at any given moment

review_title: Best place to learn how NOT to run an organization.
pros: Coworkers become like family.  Tuition remission is a nice benefit. You get a decent amount of PTO as well.
cons: In order to be successful, you have to suck up to the right people.  You are nothing more than an expendable resource.  Management doesn't care about their employees and good luck getting your leave requests approved.  The office politics are enough to make you pull your hair out.  Avoid this organization at all costs if you're able to.

pros: UMUC prides itself on trying to stay at the forefront in adult education.  With that in mind UMUC is always striving for excellence and as a result there is an inherent culture of constant change.  I truly enjoy this environment as its always an adventure working at UMUC!
cons: In order to succeed at UMUC, you must embrace change.  Over the years, I've seen people such as myself thrive in this environment and others not so much.

pros: UMUC has great staff to work with. Innovative thinking and programming as well. The benefits are under USM, which are very good, as well as the paid vacation and sick leave.
cons: Favoritism runs rampant at UMUC....which is how you get promoted. There is also a big salary discrepancy between the academic/student affairs units and units under the Office of the President. There are similar titles and responsibilities, but if you work under the academic units, your salary will be at least 10-15% less.

pros: The people are high quality and focused on the mission of providing a quality education to working professionals who need a alternative way to earn their degree.
cons: The leadership is inconsistent with their goals, communication to employees, and implementation and execution of initiatives that will make a difference to their partners and future students.

job_title: Administrative Assistant I in Largo, MD
pros: I thoroughly enjoyed my time working at UMUC. I had the opportunity to developed my administrative skills, event planning, organizational tools and use of discernment. I also made life long friends.
cons: At the time I worked at UMUC, the departments needed reassignment. It was confusing to the students as to who they were calling for what need they may have had. Therefore, there was a lot  of confusion and frustrations expressed by students.

job_title: Assistant Director in Upper Marlboro, MD
pros: Phenomenal colleagues, flex time, adequate telework policy, opportunities to attend seminars and/or conferences, tuition remission policy, great time off package.
cons: Salaries could be better, more so on-par with standard yearly increases comparable to the market. Promotions are few and far between, due to lack of space "at the top".

pros:
Helpful coworkers
Decent benefits including free parking
Nice newly remodeled offices in Adelphi and up to date office space in Largo
good faculty that provide quality higher education opportunities
cons:
Restructuring and reorganization have left staff guessing about layoffs
Vision of management not communicated to staff
It seems some departments have a growing budget while others are being cut
No emphasis on growing the careers of the staff through training opportunities
COLA in 2014 is first salary increase for all employees in many years

pros:
GREAT leave 
Tuition Remission
Awesome colleagues
The pay is pretty decent
cons:
If you are looking for a real higher education job, this isn't it.
It is a call center - high inbound and outbound volume.
Managers micromanage more than anywhere I have ever worked.

review_title: UMUC is a great place to work!  Great human resources team.
pros: Human Resources. We have an employee talent show each year.  Great benefits and time off.  Great President Javier Miyares.  He is a visionary.  We also have a great chief human resources officer John Petrov who really is there and cares for the employees.
cons: Need to grow in the United States.

review_title: I have worked at UMUC for almost two years and it has been extremely frustrating.
pros: The pros at UMUC are that it provides decent pay, a WONDERFUL amount of sick leave, vacation time and personal days, paid holidays and young and friendly co-workers.
cons: As an admissions counselor/advisor, there is no job security. They can let you go without notice and without having to offer you an explanation as a contingent 2 employee. Also, management micromanages.

pros: It's a great place to work.  Good people and purposeful mission.  We put our student's first.  We have a great HR leader John Petrov.  He had to clean up shop and has developed a strong team.  Customer service is excellent.
cons: Wish we had more locations throughout the country to allow greater mobility.  We support military and as a military spouse I would like to be able to relocate with my husband.

review_title: Great if you can play politics
pros: State benefits of leave, sick, holidays, pension, offer telework or flex scheduling.
cons: No transparency, favoritism and double standards in the office.  In the Financial Aid Office no promotion with in beyond Assistant Director.  If you are looking to grow in this department you won't get any where.  Overworked doing other people's jobs.  Quick to "celebrate" your losses before ever mentioning how you can be better.

review_title: A great place to get started, but move on Quickly (repeat quickly)
pros: Good opportunity to advance quickly, tuition remission up to 9 semester hours, great place to start your career.
cons: Very poorly managed with support from the Chancellor.  Many of good people get caught in politics and are escorted out the door quickly, thus ruining there stellar careers.  You must move on before they move you on.  I have seen far too many people get shown the door and everyone has questions.

pros: Great benefits and lots of vacation time. Great mission and stated values. Staff I worked with were predominently good people, in and out of the office.
cons: Their "students first" value is laughable...the difficulty in becoming and remaining a student is stuff of legend in the organization. Senior management is extremely insular and distrustful of mid-level and front-line staff. Very little room for promotion...nearly all senior hires in my department were from outside the company.

review_title: Only worth it if you take advantage of education benefits
pros: Free classes (although you do need to pay taxes on grad classes over 5k/year), VERY generous amounts of leave, set schedule day-to-day
cons: A call center position, focus on metrics but won't explain how metics are calculated, terrible scheduling, do not care about you as an individual, treats you like a child, monitors calls and computer screens, bad atmosphere, no option for telework despite being an online university, no freedom to make choices or think critically, phone script to follow, can't get a raise

review_title: Stay away from Ops and Planning leadership.  We need change.
pros: Good pay, great benefits and nice work colleagues.
cons: Some senior leaders are psycho here at UMUC.  Stay away from Ops and Planning leadership.  Its a sad day for project management team.  Mean and unscrupulous leadership needs to change.

job_title: Service Desk Analyst in North Brentwood, MD
pros: Friendly work atmosphere; nice vacation time, benefits and awesome co-workers. There is also room to grow, voice your opinions on certain issues at the service desk. Meetings every Friday to recap and display future announcements.
cons: Very fast pace at times. On call phone could cause your weekends to be spent at home. The on call phone has an SOP guideline that helps the Analyst handle issues; the only problem is that the Analyst must have the phone and laptop with them everywhere they go invade an issue was to arise

pros: Most senior staff is very knowledgeable and motivated. They use their knowledge to mentor staff and focus on professional development. The organization is working towards becoming a preferred employer which will be beneficial to employees in the future.
cons: Unstable working environment with constant transitions and realignment of personnel. The overseas divisions are not taken into consideration when making policy changes and when introducing new procedures. Employees in the overseas divisions are often left feeling under appreciated.

pros: Hybrid classes are once a week, usually 7-10pm at UMD.  Students are mainly adults. Online classes can be taught from home or laptop.
cons: 8 week semesters, usually only one class per semester. Must work semester to semester and sometimes nothing is available next semester. Pay rate is low for the amount of work expected. UMUC does not pay you for the time it takes to build your class - usually several weeks. No benefits.

pros: Great Pay, lots of off time available
cons:
Micromanagement, Advising is basically run like a call center. There is someone watching your every move. 

Because it's run as a call center, student's do not view advisers as legitimate. They act as if we are their personal assistants/ customer service reps. There is no responsibility placed upon students to make informed decisions about their education.

pros: There are many great people within the university that truly wants to make a great difference for the students and the institution.
cons: Upper Management Responsible for managing strategic initiatives is the source of toxicity. Insincerity and lack of trust towards a selective few within the team, and preferential treatment towards others who agree with the leader’s toxic methods.

job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Adelphi, MD
pros:
Great place to work! Work-Life Balance and Telecommuting are important. Amazing benefits as state employee verses being in private sector.
Competent and respectful people, relaxed environment, sense of purpose, well organized and managed, highly affordable benefits options, extra benefits through USM, etc.
cons: Commuting back and forth between the two campus offices can be a bit exhausting at times. No real on-site food options at Adelphi office.

job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Largo, MD
pros:
Best things to look forward to as a regular, non-contractual employee.

1) Leave. 5 weeks of paid leave is ridiculous for a starting position or any mid-career position. Most other universities don't even offer that until 15-20 years of service.
2) Tuition Remission. 

These two make working here and the lower amount of pay worth it.
cons: Largo is hard to get to, so commutes can be difficult. Although it is right off of the beltway and that makes things a lot easier.

pros: The team and work environment within the Strategic Enrollment Management department at UMUC were outstanding. The compensation and benefits are also exceptional for entry-level employees.
cons: This is not a position for individuals who prefer to work with customers or students face-to-face. This is a phone-based position. Your incoming and outgoing calls are monitored and reviewed. There is no sense of quality over quantity. It seems to be all about numbers. It is very easy to become discouraged within this position.

pros: Leave  and co-workers, Great leave time
cons: Management could use training, they don't listen to employees, the micromanagement,  paranoia and advising atmosphere is terrible, people leave like every week!  and if they have not left they are trying to leave, the place is like the movie "GET OUT" literally! This department is poorly managed. I would not recommend it, and training is survivor island, feels more cutthroat, definitely not like you're being trained. Students are misadvised because advisors are not supported, they are more worried about sales campaigns than actual students and employees

review_title: UMUC has great VP HR John Petrov and great HR Team!
job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Largo, MD
pros: Love working here.  Great pay and benefits.  Great HR team and leadership.  We now have online rewards and recognition for all global faculty and staff.  Employees have a voice with annual engagement surveys.
cons: Growth mindset too much.

review_title: Run! Don't Stop or Look back! Layoffs! Micromanagement! Call Center! Burn Out Job!
job_title: Academic Advisor/Admissions Counselor in Largo, MD
pros: Tuition Remission, Vacation Days- you can earn a degree for free..IF YOU CAN STAND THE JOB LONG ENOUGH!
cons:
RUN! Do not stop. Advisors & Admissions Counselors are call center agents and salespeople. Not True Advisors. KNOW that this is a BURN OUT job. You will get sick between awful, ever changing managers, Unfair ratings of call QA, and PRESSURE from management. NUMBERS, NUMBERS, NUMBERS! By the end, I felt like dying! 

MANY employees quit this job. Managers quit also. Way Too Much turnover!! I watched some people quit just after training completion and/or before they made it out of training even. Job NOT intended for staying more than 2 years tops. Childish behavior from mangers and coworkers.  Every year, a new restructuring, recycling past standards of operation. MANY LAYOFFS of good employees without fair notice, incl severance. I literally watched SOO many people come to work at 9am and walk out Terminated by 9:15am. One lady sat right ACROSS from me. Very SAD and UNCOMFORTABLE working environment. This includes long-term and newly hired employees. Too many reorganizations, resulting in more job duties, no pay increase. Contingent employees can be FIRED for ANY reason at ANY time. NO JOB SECURITY for Advisors or Admissions Counselors.

NO TRUE Job Growth. You had to create a huge book of "look at what I've done" and practically beg for next level increase, which could be denied for ANY reason manager wanted to use.

CALL CENTER environment, with WAY TOO MUCH micromanagement. One min late, and your job is THREATENED. Employees are not valued, or listened to. PRESSURE to take inbound calls and make outbound calls NONSTOP, whether you are properly trained or not in some instances on changing outreach campaigns. And some of them are just stupid/busy work.

Your JOB title can be switched and come along with more responsibility when the company decides to do so...AND the BEST PART........WITHOUT EFFECTIVE TRAINING!!

No true way to manage/measure performance, as there is no real averaging because EACH employees call amount, call duration, and workload will differ..day in and day out. Yet, they try to rate your performance on some Imagined average!  AND this FAKE average can be used against you for termination.

Promotions....GOOD LUCK! if you are not a YES MAN/WOMAN or in the "FAVORITES" you will grow old with dust and cobwebs before you see any real job growth. They pick who they like and know, or the kiss ups.

Oh the best part, managers will HOUND you about a 1 min late arrival or return from lunch, but THEY WILL BE LATE THEMSELVES.  AND Policy can be changed, made up to be different between departments or COMPLETELY IGNORED by management. HR DOES NOT support advisors.

Finally, UMUC/management does not pay for parties, food, etc for departmental meetings, events, etc. They have monthly  POTLUCKS, and expect employees to ALWAYS pay for their own food/supplies, etc. We had to bring in our own food/supplies and stuff. PATHETIC! Every BLUE MOON..on  Old Hallowes Eve, they will buy lunch for employees.

pros: We have great management who care about our employees and students.  They hold us accountable and do have high performance expectations.  That makes me proud to serve our students.  We have competitions and get a lot of recognition.
cons: Would like higher pay and be able to receive spot award when I do something great.

review_title: Get what you can, then GET OUT of SEM
pros:
-paycheck
-good co-workers, you will build great rapport
-opportunity to take on more responsibilities
-comfortable location to work, nice building
cons:
-only constant is change
-high turn over
-hiring within, not guaranteed,
-burn out is inevitable

review_title: Working here is a great power move otherwise run
pros: Tuition remission, leave time accrues fast, prepares you for that '1 year minimum' requirement in other jobs in higher education so you can run away
cons: When you first get hired you will be working Tue - Sat 11:00am to 8:00pm. and if you take two Saturdays off they will be speaking to you right away. They will watch your computer screen and monitor your calls. And if you were wondering if there was a script? There is and you have to follow it. When you call someone you have to say "This call will be recorded for quality purposes" every time ruining the flow of any conversation and making you sound like a robot. You will then have to have coaching sessions and you will sit in their office listening to the call and them go on about how if you did not take someone's information but still helped any way that we lost thousands of dollars. You will be participating in a call center.  Don't be fooled into thinking this is an occasional on the phone position. They expect you to make calls back to back all the hours of your shift.  You get 15 minutes of walk away time per day so if you enjoy basic human needs like going to the bathroom or getting a snack you will run through that time very quickly.  They use the calls you make in a day to determine if you are productive or not and if you are not meeting their goals you will be passed over for a raise. The ADs spend all day running around to others' offices gossiping and micromanaging you. Right now I am writing this in May 2018, there will be 15 people leaving by the second week of June. If that does not tell you about how people feel about this place I don't know what will. You even have to be in that position for a year before you apply for any other jobs that will be handed over internally to friends and shmoozers.

pros: The people are great, the facilities are modern.  The pay was actually decent, not horrible.  There was never any raises, but that didn't bother me too much.
cons: The higher-ups are completely disconnected from what happens on a daily basis. They make ridiculous decisions about how we should do our jobs.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Silver Spring, MD
pros: Nice people. Plenty of leave time given.
cons: Healthcare premiums are not payroll deducted, so they must be paid after taxes...expensive. Call center approach to advising students.  Micromanagement through rigid policies. Low morale among peers. Ambiguous process for advancement.

pros: A job, benefits, plenty of time off, educational benefits IF you can take it long enough.
cons: You don't want to work here if you have any good experience working in IT support. They don't like it when you can think for yourself, or if you have any good ideas or even if you want to actually help the people you are supporting. They discourage any interaction between departments, sharing information is discouraged because everyone is just looking out for their own job security. Management doesn't like anyone having more experience or knowledge than they do. They basically want people to just say yes or how high

review_title: As a Professor's Assistant, I am able to inspire students giving them new ideas and keep fresh on current EMS's
job_title: Professor's Assistant in Silver Spring, MD
pros: Professors are easy to work with and value your helping students, as well as considerate of ideas and suggestions. Online teaching. I learn with the students and their sponsors as we research various environmental management systems.
cons: Online teaching can be impersonal.

pros: A lot of time is spent on the phones, but I knew that during the interview process. Pay is great for right of college and the managers do  listen to our ideas. I made a suggestion and the VP heard it and came and thanked me and asked me to work on the project.
cons: I have a fairly long commute.

pros: If you can manage to stay with UMUC, the state benefits are great.  there are no more IT functions - see Cons.
cons: The President is determined to outsource everything except for instruction under the guise of creating income producing companies.  He outsourced IT into Accelered and Helocampus, both of which are not producing any income but instead costing the tax payers more money.  It seems this was a move to remove state employees especially those with Pensions and provide less costly benefits.  Ironically, the board of directors for these companies are making pretty good money.

review_title: Advisors Run! You have been warned!
job_title: Admissions Associate Advisor in Largo, MD
pros: Time off/Leave is the only pro
cons:
I work for the Admissions department. The job duties, pay and hours that they told me in the interview were totally different than how things actually were when I started. They lied about almost everything. Then if you complain, they'll tell you that you need to be flexible in this position. Everyone has one foot out of the door. The training process was horrible! Almost 2 months of training and you're sitting in a classroom the entire time staring at the trainers. You can't use your phone, limited bathroom breaks and no talking. Let me not forget to mention all your phone calls to students are monitored. Management is able to view everything on your computer screen (all tabs!). Don't get it twisted, this is a call center! They use salesforce and treat students as if they're customers. Students submitting an application is the sale! They monitor your every move! Be aware that they will have no problem firing you if they feel like you don't have "the right skill set" or if you're not being productive enough by calling students back to back. Also, they have a new training class that starts every month because the turnover is so high! In each  monthly training class there are about  10 people that start, but only 1 person ends up staying. Watch out for your managers (The ADs) they are not on your side. Watch your back. I do not recommend this job!!! I'm actively looking for a new job.

This warning goes for Academic Advisors too. Same thing- different title. 
Oh, and be aware that there is a maximum on tuition assistance benefits. Ask about the limits.

review_title: Too much disconnect between upper management and lower level staff.
pros: Great benefits, good vacation time, decent training opportunities.
cons: Lower level staff expected to follow through on every order without any clarity on how it helps the organization's mission.  Lower level employees are treated like children because of the behavior of a small group.

review_title: UMUC offers opportunities to teach upper-level courses that are normally not available to adjuncts
pros:
In the upper-level classes, the students are competent and motivated
Supportive administration 
Flexible scheduling, since most classes are online
Pays a bit more than other local colleges
cons:
UMUC is pretty prescriptive in its online platform and in course content
The eight-week semesters reduce the quality of instruction/learning and make it difficult to keep up with the workload.

job_title: Military and Veteran Advisor in Largo, MD
pros: I really enjoyed my coworkers. There was a gym and cafe available for employees on the premises.
cons: It is basically a call center environment. You will not see any students face-to-face. I had a case load of 2,000 students and was assigned approx 20-30 new students alone each day which is too many students to effectively walk through the enrollment process while completing all of the que calls and other daily tasks. The pay is poor for MD area (less than 40K/year), The management uses scare tactics and expects more than anyone could ever complete in an 8 hour period. Expect that most of your coworkers will be fresh out of college and terrified of losing their job. When I was there, many employees stayed after their shift an additional 4 hours to try to complete work they could never get to because they were in the que taking calls all day. If you have a family, you will need to stay late too to keep up with the productivity of your coworkers. Supervisors would be known to sit in your cubicle and ream you in front of your coworkers for ridiculous mistakes they felt you made on your calls. One example would be that you did not look up the answer to a question (such as what date registration ended for that semester). It may have been something you answered 300 times already, but they still wanted you to physically look it up in the manual. It just seemed like they were looking for reasons to let you know they were in control. It was definitely a hostile work environment in my opinion. It was the worst job of 4 I have had in my work history.

pros: Great benefits when it comes to having your schooling paid for while your with UMUC. Ample parking, and a full week of during Christmas holiday.
cons: If you don't have a degree, you not able to get compatible salary in comparison to similar jobs in the job market.

pros: Good hours, flexible schedule, easy job, casual work environment, onsite cafeteria with good food, opportunity to help students
cons: Low pay for amount of work expected, Call center environment with heavy coaching. Health benefit stipend is not enough, benefits should be included in pay, which should be higher.

job_title: Military Education Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros: Reliable pay check. A lot of PTO and you get tuition remission. It's a great stepping stone to bigger things
cons: No compensation for being a good or even above average employee. The yearly review that they make you put effort into yields 1-3 perfect increase and it will be the exact same as the slacker sitting next to you

review_title: Great company if you are in the good with your supervisor
pros:
Great coworkers, moving up is open if you are willing to work. 
Volunteer for projects and be innovative. 
Make changes, make things easier.
cons: Salary is mediocre and doesn't provide much for reward.

review_title: Great, until the current IT leadership came on board and IT infrastructure was outsourced
pros: The IT staff was loyal and dedicated to keeping the existing online learning systems up and running.   The IT staff understood the university's mission and had a personal investment in making sure the online learning experience was the best it could be given that WebTycho is dated and should've been abandoned long ago.
cons: I will say that UMUC has never had good IT leadership  This is mostly due to the fact that the academic side has no real understanding of the importance of IT.  Their only concern is, "are the systems up and accessible".   They also had a bad habit of promoting from within and moving people up into prominent positions even though they had never worked anywhere other than UMUC ... since graduating college.  The President's office never had a sense of urgency to replace WebTycho with Blackboard or another off-the-shelf product so they could focus on the content and features offered to the students.  They dumped way too much money in keeping WebTycho and Peoplesoft limping along.  Now instead of making the correct changes, they want to put the university's main asset in the cloud.  This is wrong on so many levels, not to mention all the money wasted on building a new top-of-the-line data center in 2012.

job_title: Executive Administrative Assistant II in Adelphi, MD
pros:
Time off is generous, tuition remission, flexible work schedule. 

I believe one's experience differs based on position and department. I work with an eclectic group of individuals, but we mesh very well. A lot of professional expertise and room for growth. No micro managing within our department!
cons: Not easily accessible by public transportation.

job_title: Executive Director, Payroll in Adelphi, MD
pros: Excellent benefits, paid holidays, retirement, paid time-off, tuition remission.  UMUC is working very hard to be considered the Employer of Choice
cons: I think as a predominantly online university that UMUC should allow more than a maximum of two days per week for teleworking as long as the job that is held is considered 100% portable.

review_title: UMUC is best seen in a rear view mirror
job_title: Education Coordinator in North East, MD
pros: GREAT front line staff. Colleagues were knowledgeable and helpful. Students would be lost without the advisors.
cons: Horrible leadership and management. The business model is to only help students who are having issues. By that time it's usually too late. Recruitment is high-pressure sales (think timeshares and used cars) and new enrollment numbers are paramount to everything else (including student retention numbers).

pros: Paid time off and benefits. That’s the only thing that may keep you here..utilizing tuition remission and the paid time off
cons: I’ve been training as an academic advisor and it’s very sales and numbers based. YOU ARE NOT A REAL ADVISOR but a customer service/ sales rep..I’m currently looking for another job. If you are good with selling a product and have extroverted social skills...maybe you can make it. There is a reason why they are hiring people every month!!!

pros: People were great to with
cons: Unbearably micromanaged. Job description was very misleading and the job was not what they told me it would be. Was just a call center where you memorize a script. Turnover rate was crazy, no one seemed to want to stay. My assumption is because of the high expectations and the amount of cold calling that had to be done.

pros: Having taught courses for a number of different schools both ground and online, it's nice to work with a place like UMUC that does it right.  Instructors are treated fairly, our opinions are valued, and compensation is fair (at least for the discipline in which I teach).
cons: None -- I love it here.  Only wish I could get in full time

pros: The people, and benefits. As I worked in UMUC Europe, I had the advantage of being able to travel a lot. UMUC Europe was fun to work for, until they relocated the headquarters office.
cons: UMUC Europe is now located in K-town, it is not located in Heidelberg anymore. Location is not accessible with public transportation unless you have a car.

pros: Good Pay and lots of paid time off
cons: Micro management, Pretty much a call center, It is not academic advising it is a complaint line (customer service).

pros: UMUC has great benefits, PTO and tuition remission. It is a decent work life balance. Also get a week off during the holidays.
cons: Their upper management is horrible. They instill fear in their employees they can get fired at any time. Fear you are going to lose your job.

pros: Math and Stat department is great!
cons: Unfortunately, the Dean 'fired' all collegiate faculty which impacts not only faculty salaries and their living BUT the continuity that a full-time faculty was once able to provide.

review_title: Do not work at UMUC, not a competitive work place, poor location, terrible leadership
pros: inexpensive cafeteria food, free education for employees
cons: Incompetent, volatile, psychotic executive level staff. Executive Staff treats the employees like children, complete lack of professionalism from senior management and HR.  Enrollment at UMUC is down due to poor curriculum development and bogus courses, faculty on staff without a Masters in Education or PhD., con artists disguised as business professionals hired  to create chaos and discord.

review_title: Great place, great people, and why did I leave again??
pros: The people, professional environment, and even ambiance... Even though that sounds a bit strange! The facilities are all extremely up-dated and technology is second to none.
cons: Location is not metro-accessible and very difficult to get to if you don't have a car. I probably would not have accepted a job there if I didn't have one.

pros: Teach online classes. Have complete autonomy and flexibility.
cons: Class sizes can be large, and you are encouraged to be very generous in passing students.

pros: Love working with my Chair. Very knowledgeable and staff is on-top. I've worked at a few online schools as a part-timer and this is the best. I've worked at UMUC > 12 years, so that says it all.
cons: None known and I've been working here quite a long time.

pros:
100% tuition remission with UMUC and %'s off other MD
Major holidays off and Christmas day thru New Year's Day off every year.
Lots of leave
cons: Lots of turnover. Upper management keeps changing hands so the projects are constantly being changed or forgotten. No idea how the different sites run or that the sites exist.

pros: Teaching accounting subjects is my line and I love teaching accounting, taxation, and auditing subjects.
cons: Meeting people with diverse culture and different style of management.

pros: Online environment works well with professional students.  Online interface is convenient and instructor interaction effective for working adults.  Knowledgeable instruction with experienced teaching staff.
cons: Online environment tool needs an upgrade but effective.  Class size is above average but manageable.

review_title: Not like any other higher education institution. UMUC embraces diversity, innovation and investing in its people.
pros: Investing in professional development, telework, benefits, pay, people, changing environment.
cons: State laws and regulations can cause hold up on getting things done.

pros:
-friendly staff
-opportunity for growth
-truly shows appreciation for employees
-prides itself on making a difference in students lives
-offers amazing benefits
-nice hours
-great location
cons:
-if you do your work well, you are forced to complete the work of others who are less efficient
